symptoms.name: Primary lesion (Mother Yaw)
symptoms.severity: Variable, can be indolent or ulcerative
symptoms.pattern: Single lesion at inoculation site, evolves into papilloma or ulcer

symptoms.name: Papilloma
symptoms.pattern: Wart-like tumor, 2-5 cm, often on limbs

symptoms.name: Ulcer
symptoms.pattern: Single ulcer covered by yellow crust, often on legs and ankles

symptoms.name: Secondary yaws
symptoms.severity: Variable, can be mild or severe
symptoms.pattern: Multiple raised yellow lesions, pain and swelling of long bones and fingers (dactylitis), skin rash, macules, papules, pustules, or crusted lesions

symptoms.name: Late yaws
symptoms.pattern: Gummata, extensive skin lesions, bone destruction, neurological involvement

symptoms.name: Pain
symptoms.severity: Variable, can be severe in dactylitis and late-stage lesions
symptoms.pattern: Associated with dactylitis and plantar lesions

symptoms.name: Swelling
symptoms.severity: Variable, can be severe in dactylitis

lab_values.PCR: Detects T. pallidum pertenue DNA in skin lesions

risk_factors: Living in poor communities in warm, humid tropical areas

required: Clinical presentation consistent with yaws (papilloma, ulcer, or other characteristic lesions)
Positive serological test (TPPA or RPR), although these tests do not distinguish yaws from syphilis
supportive: Positive PCR for T. pallidum pertenue DNA
Epidemiological factors (exposure to yaws in endemic area)
